revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Taxobox | image = Calocera cornea 38121.jpg | image_width = 234px | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Dacrymycetes]] | ordo = [[Dacrymycetales]] | familia = [[Dacrymycetaceae]] | genus = ''[[Calocera]]'' | species = '''''C. cornea''''' | binomial = ''Calocera cornea'' | binomial_authority = ([[August Batsch|Batsch]]) [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]] (1827) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = ''Clavaria cornea'' Batsch (1783)
''Corynoides cornea'' (Batsch) [[Samuel Frederick Gray|Gray]] (1821)
''Calocera cornes'' (Batsch) Fr. (1827) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Calocera cornea'' | hymeniumType=smooth | whichGills = no | capShape = no | stipeCharacter=bare | ecologicalType= saprotrophic | sporePrintColor=white | howEdible=unknown}} {{commonscat}} '''''Calocera cornea''''' is a jelly fungus that grows on decaying wood. It is a member of the [[Dacrymycetales]], an order of fungi characterized by their unique "tuning fork" [[basidia]]. Its yellow, finger-like, tapering [[basidiocarp]]s are somewhat gelatinous in texture. In typical specimens the basidiocarps become up to 3 mm in diameter, and 2 cm in height. The [[hymenium]] covers the sides of the basidiocarps, each basidium producing and forcibly discharging only two basidiospores. ==References== *C.J. Alexopolous, Charles W. Mims, M. Blackwell et al., ''Introductory Mycology, 4th ed.'' (John Wiley and Sons, Hoboken NJ, 2004) {{ISBN|0-471-52229-5}} *McNabb R.F.R. 1965a. Taxonomic studies in the Dacrymycetaceae II. ''Calocera'' (Fries) Fries. New Zealand J. Bot. 3: 31–58. *[http://www.messiah.edu/Oakes/fungi_on_wood/club%20and%20coral/species%20pages/Calocera%20cornea.htm Messiah.edu] {{Taxonbar|from=Q175548}} ==External links== *[https://earthlingnature.wordpress.com/2019/03/01/friday-fellow-club-like-tuning-fork/ Friday Fellow: Club-like Tuning Fork] at Earthling Nature.
